justification: The authors list word reading accuracy as the first of several literacy measures and later state that these scores were used to form the composite index of reading ability.
The methods section specifies “one-minute word” reading as one of the three reading measures contributing to the reading-ability factor.
Pseudoword reading fluency is named alongside word reading accuracy and word reading fluency as part of the confirmatory factor analysis for reading ability.
Among the cognitive and literacy tests, the study lists 'phoneme deletion,' indicating this task was administered to index phonological awareness.
The battery included ‘rapid automatised naming of (5) letters,’ identifying this as the instrument for assessing rapid naming speed.
The same sentence notes ‘rapid automatised naming of … (6) digits,’ serving as a second RAN measure.
Participants ‘first completed … (1) a 36-trial recognition task’ within the PAL experiment, making this task the operational measure of paired-associate learning.
The PAL experiment also included ‘(2) a 12-trial cued-recall task,’ which the authors analyse as another indicator of PAL performance.

The paper explains that they ‘modelled three mouse curvature indices, namely maximum absolute deviation (MAD), average deviation (AD), and area under the curve (AUC),’ to capture online decision processes while performing PAL.
The methods note that ‘Nonverbal intelligence quotient (IQ) data was obtained in a different session,’ signifying a separate test used to gauge nonverbal cognitive ability.
